To Provide Fuses
Johns Hopkins established the
Applied Physics Laboratory in
1942 to develop a proximity fuse
for artillery shells. The production of the fuse has been described as one of the major developments of the war.
Since 1945 the laboratory has
been engaged in guided-missile
research and development for the
Naval Bureau of Ordnance. The
Bumblebee program, which the
laboratory directs, has produced
the Terrier guided missile, now
in operational use on the USS
Boston and the USS Canberra,
heavy cruisers, and the USS
Gyatt, a destroyer.
Another missile, the ramjetpowered Tabs, provides the
main armament of the cruiser
USS Galveston, which was commissioned in May and is expected
to join the fleet shortly. A third
missile, the Tartar, is under development.
